title: Figma adds three AI image tools to keep designers out of Photoshop

paragraphs.content: Figma has introduced three new AI-powered image editing tools—**Erase object**, **Isolate object**, and **Expand image**—designed to bring precise, Photoshop-style tweaks directly onto the design canvas.The update lets designers remove unwanted elements, separate subjects, and extend image backgrounds to new aspect ratios without leaving Figma Design or Draw.By operating on selections instead of text prompts, the tools aim to give teams granular control over layouts and marketing assets while avoiding the trial-and-error of generative commands.

paragraphs.content: A short Figma video walkthrough shows the tools living inside a revamped image-editing toolbar, which consolidates existing options like Crop and Remove background with the new AI features for faster, contextual access.Beyond the design surface, Figma is also promoting a no-code AI photo editing app builder in Figma Make, signaling that the same underlying capabilities can power custom image workflows.On its broader AI product page, the company highlights integrations with models such as Google’s Gemini 3.0 Pro and OpenAI’s GPT Image 1, positioning the new editing tools as part of a larger ecosystem of assisted creativity.

sections.title: What Erase, Isolate, and Expand actually do on the Figma canvas

paragraphs.content: ContentGrip reports that Erase object lets users select and remove stray props, logos, or background clutter directly in Figma, eliminating the common export–edit–reimport loop with external tools.Isolate object, by contrast, segments a subject so it can be moved or styled independently—making it easier to adjust placement, lighting, or focus while leaving the original background intact.Expand image uses AI to extend an image’s background so a single product shot can be repurposed across multiple aspect ratios, such as turning a 1:1 social image into a wide web banner without awkward cropping.

paragraphs.content: A Figma demo clip shows these tools triggered from an inline toolbar that appears when an image is selected, allowing designers to lasso an area, erase it, isolate it as a new object, or expand the canvas in a few clicks.The company’s AI overview notes that image editing in Figma increasingly relies on a mix of generative and refinement models, with Gemini 3.0 Pro and GPT Image 1 handling both new-image creation and targeted adjustments.Figma’s AI Image Editor plugin in the Community further illustrates how similar capabilities can be exposed through text prompts, though the new native tools are explicitly selection-first rather than prompt-driven.

sections.title: Why Figma’s “precision AI” matters for workflows and the wider AI stack

paragraphs.content: ContentGrip frames the launch as Figma “finally jumping into precision AI image editing,” arguing that marketers and product teams gain measurable efficiency when routine tweaks stay inside the design file.The article notes that these tools help non-specialists adapt assets for different channels, reducing dependencies on dedicated designers for every minor crop or cleanup.Figma’s AI page underscores that philosophy, describing its AI suite as a way to “make, edit, and refine images” in context, alongside features like instant background removal and automated layer renaming to keep projects organized.

paragraphs.content: On the no-code side, Figma Make’s AI photo editing app builder shows how the same model infrastructure can be used to prototype full editing experiences, from quick style variations to more precise controls powered by models like Gemini 3 Pro and Figma’s branded “Nano Banana Pro.”The Make documentation emphasizes that teams can describe an editing app in natural language and generate interactive layouts, hinting at a future where Figma’s own image tools and customer-built tools share common AI underpinnings.Together, these developments suggest Figma is moving beyond wireframing toward a platform where AI-assisted editing, layout, and even app logic live in a single, collaborative environment.
